docs.snippet: NEW YORK (AP) — In a story Dec. 17 about travel to Cuba, The Associated Press reported erroneously the number of Americans who were authorized to travel to Cuba last year. The number was 124,000, not 170,000....
docs.lead_paragraph: NEW YORK (AP) — In a story Dec. 17 about travel to Cuba, The Associated Press reported erroneously the number of Americans who were authorized to travel to Cuba last year. The number was 124,000, not 170,000.

docs.snippet: The uncertain security situation in Iraq prompted the State Department to issue a mixed message today.     The department lifted a restriction on the use of United States passports to travel to Iraq, ending a travel ban for most Americans that had...
docs.lead_paragraph: The uncertain security situation in Iraq prompted the State Department to issue a mixed message today. The department lifted a restriction on the use of United States passports to travel to Iraq, ending a travel ban for most Americans that had been in effect since the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait in 1990.
docs.abstract: State Department lifts restriction on use of US passports for travel to Iraq, but warns of dangerous situation there (S)

headline.main: All Right to Visit Iraq Now, or Is It?

docs.snippet: TRENTON, Nov. 21 -- The New Jersey Supreme Court today upheld the right of the Borough of Palisades Park to prohibit the erection of motels. Such an enterprise, the Bergen County community had argued, would impair existing property values....
docs.lead_paragraph: TRENTON, Nov. 21 -- The New Jersey Supreme Court today upheld the right of the Borough of Palisades Park to prohibit the erection of motels. Such an enterprise, the Bergen County community had argued, would impair existing property values.
docs.abstract: NJ Sup Ct, 4-3, upholds Palisades Pk Boro right to ban motels

headline.main: TOP JERSEY COURT BACKS MOTEL BAN; Right of Palisades Park to Protect Property Values Is Upheld on Appeal

byline.original: Special to The New York Times

docs.snippet: VIENNA, July 28 -- United States Army suspicion that Russian geologists wished to hunt uranium ores in the American zone of Austria brought a Russian ultimatum in the matter of passes through the Russian zone last week. Accordingly the Russians no...
docs.lead_paragraph: VIENNA, July 28 -- United States Army suspicion that Russian geologists wished to hunt uranium ores in the American zone of Austria brought a Russian ultimatum in the matter of passes through the Russian zone last week. Accordingly the Russians now refuse to give any consideration to American applications for passes to go to or through the Soviet zone.
docs.abstract: US ban on USSR geologists, US zone, Austria, because of suspected hunt for ore, disclosed; USSR reprisal noted

headline.main: SOVIET IN AUSTRIA BARS AMERICANS; Russian Action in Zone Follows Our Ban on Suspected Hunt for Uranium Ores

byline.original: By ALBION ROSSSpecial to THE NEW YORK TIMES
